biography.background: The line of Gial is supposed to maintain the pre-Umbrian art of infusing the Schnaps with the powers of healing and restoration, but that knowlege was lost when Gial IV. died before Gial V. mastered those infusions. Instead he had wasted too much time in searching for the mythic knowledge of The Last Professor, Gial (you don't number the original, in hindsight you do, so Gial I.), once it was the search for power, now, having let his people down, it is about redemption. The master of the distillery is a powerful rival, always reminding the community and Gial V., that it is Gial's fault that the Schnaps' powers have diminished as much as they did -- not his fault (Gial expects that maybe the slow corruption of the Umbra played a part and it is not completely his fault that he lost the powers of the highly distilled spirits. But he would not tell anyone before he has any proof—better to be guilty than being guilty and denying it, too.
biography.connections:
To Talokai: "If I don't make it, make sure this tome handed down through the generations of my family finds someone, not of the Grand Ordinates, who understands it. Find some Aetherweaver or Lorekeeper who... understands."

Talokai's Response: “If it comes to that I will see it done. No Ordinates. No careless hands. Whoever takes it will understand—and honor it. You have my word.”

system.description: Gain an additional Stress slot at character creation.

effects.name: High Stamina
effects.description: Gain an additional Stress slot at character creation.

system.description: When you fail a roll that utilized one of your Experiences, you can mark a Stress to reroll.

Humans are most easily recognized by their dexterous hands, rounded ears, and bodies built for endurance.

Their average height ranges from just under 5 feet to about 6 ½ feet. They have a wide variety of builds, with some being quite broad, others lithe, and many inhabiting the spectrum in between. Humans are physically adaptable and adjust to harsh climates with relative ease. In general, humans live to an age of about 100, with their bodies changing dramatically between their youngest and oldest years.
You have advantage on rolls that involve the history, culture, or politics of a prominent person or place.

effects.name: Well-Read

changes.value: History, culture, or politics of a prominent person or place

effects.description: Well-Read: You have advantage on rolls that involve the history, culture, or politics of a prominent person or place.

system.description:
Being part of a loreborne community means you’re from a society that favors strong academic or political prowess.

Loreborne communities highly value knowledge, frequently in the form of historical preservation, political advancement, scientific study, skill development, or lore and mythology compilation. Most members of these communities research in institutions built in bastions of civilization, while some eclectic few thrive in gathering information from the natural world. Some may be isolationists, operating in smaller enclaves, schools, or guilds and following their own unique ethos. Others still wield their knowledge on a larger scale, making deft political maneuvers across governmental landscapes.

Loreborne are often direct, eloquent, inquisitive, patient, rhapsodic, and witty.
Spend 3 Hope to force an adversary within Far range to reroll an attack or damage roll.

system.description: You can perform harmless, subtle magical effects at will. For example, you can change an object’s color, create a smell, light a candle, cause a tiny object to f loat, illuminate a room, or repair a small object.

Choose a number between 1 and 12. When you roll that number on a Duality Die, gain a Hope or clear a Stress.

You can change this number when you take a long rest.

RkqPzF1bdWzPPMml.description:

You can change this number when you take a long rest.
RkqPzF1bdWzPPMml.name: Clear Stress

system.description: Whether through an institution or individual study, those known as wizards acquire and hone immense magical power over years of learning using a variety of tools, including books, stones, potions, and herbs. Some wizards dedicate their lives to mastering a particular school of magic, while others learn from a wide variety of disciplines. Many wizards become wise and powerful figures in their communities, advising rulers, providing medicines and healing, and even leading war councils. While these mages all work toward the common goal of collecting magical knowledge, wizards often have the most conflict within their own ranks, as the acquisition, keeping, and sharing of powerful secrets is a topic of intense debate that has resulted in innumerable deaths.
Take an additional domain card of your level or lower from a domain you have access to.

system.description: Play the School of Knowledge if you want a keen understanding of the world around you.

Power Push: Make a Spellcast Roll against a target within Melee range. On a success, they’re knocked back to Far range and take d10+2 magic damage using your Proficiency.

Tava’s Armor: Spend a Hope to give a target you can touch a +1 bonus to their Armor Score until their next rest or you cast Tava’s Armor again.

Ice Spike: Make a Spellcast Roll (12) to summon a large ice spike within Far range. If you use it as a weapon, make the Spellcast Roll against the target’s Difficulty instead. On a success, deal d6 physical damage using your Proficiency.

system.description:
Slumber: Make a Spellcast Roll against a target within Very Close range. On a success, they’re Asleep until they take damage or the GM spends a Fear on their turn to clear this condition.

Arcane Barrage: Once per rest, spend any number of Hope and shoot magical projectiles that strike a target of your choice within Close range. Roll a number of d6s equal to the Hope spent and deal that much magic damage to the target.

Telepathy: Spend a Hope to open a line of mental communication with one target you can see. This connection lasts until your next rest or you cast Telepathy again.

system.description:
1. A book of scholarly writings gathered from Eornheard Wine.

  2. A book of mad, religious rants gathered from Brother Juan.

Wild Flame: Make a Spellcast Roll against up to three adversaries within Melee range. Targets you succeed against take 2d6 magic damage and must mark a Stress as flames erupt from your hand.

Magic Hand: You conjure a magical hand with the same size and strength as your own within Far range.

Mysterious Mist: Make a Spellcast Roll (13) to cast a temporary thick fog that gathers in a stationary area within Very Close range. The fog heavily obscures this area and everything in it.

system.description:
Runic Lock: Make a Spellcast Roll (15) on an object you’re touching that can close (such as a lock, chest, or box). Once per rest on a success, you can lock the object so it can only be opened by creatures of your choice. Someone with access to magic and an hour of time to study the spell can break it.

Arcane Door: When you have no adversaries within Melee range, make a Spellcast Roll (13). On a success, spend a Hope to create a portal from where you are to a point within Far range you can see. It closes once a creature has passed through it.

Reveal: Make a Spellcast Roll. If there is anything magically hidden within Close range the roll would succeed against, it is revealed.

kfJZdT3F4SH1h1dc.description: Make a Spellcast Roll (15) on an object you’re touching that can close (such as a lock, chest, or box). system.description: Clear 1d4 Stress.

This item represents enough rations to feed a character for a few days. So long as a character has this item on them when they travel, they do not suffer from the effects of hunger or thirst. If a character does not have this item on their person during a long rest taken as part of a travel narrative, they may not take the clear stress downtime action. Generally speaking, a character does not need to carry multiple uses of this item. Each item represents multiple servings of foodstuff. After a long rest, however, a GM may spend a Fear in order to force a character to make an [[/dr trait=instinct]] with a difficulty based on the terrain. On a failure, the character runs out of rations and must consume this item.

d7KcpGxuLB6kJYaV.description: Only use this action after a failed [[/dr trait=instinct]] roll invoked by a GM spending fear following a long rest.
d7KcpGxuLB6kJYaV.name: Consume

system.description:
Mystic Tether: Make a Spellcast Roll against a target within Far range. On a success, they’re temporarily Restrained and must mark a Stress. If you target a flying creature, this spell grounds and temporarily Restrains them.

Fireball: Make a Spellcast Roll against a target within Very Far range. On a success, hurl a sphere of fire toward them that explodes on impact. The target and all creatures within Very Close range of them must make a Reaction Roll (13). Targets who fail take d20+5 magic damage using your Proficiency. Targets who succeed take half damage.
